html:
2025-0925
2025-12-11ECCC, HCCanadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999Regulations Amending the PCB Regulations and the Regulations Designating Regulatory Provisions for Purposes of Enforcement (Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999)Regulations Amending the PCB Regulations and the Regulations Designating Regulatory Provisions for Purposes of Enforcement (Canadian Environment Protection Act, 1999) in order to (1) allow for the continued use and storage of polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB)-containing equipment in nuclear, electrical, and military facilities, as well as museums, subject to certain conditions; (2) clarify that mixing PCB oil with non-PCB oil for the purposes of reducing its concentration is not allowed and, that laboratory tests are not required if the PCB concentration is already known by other means; (3) defer end-of-use deadline for certain PCB-containing electrical equipment to December 31, 2026, or beyond, subject to ministerial approval; and (4) make consequential amendments to certain other regulations to incorporate the provisions of the regulations.Registration: SOR/2025-0273 Publication Date: 2025-12-31
subject: Regulations Amending the PCB Regulations and the Regulations Designating Regulatory Provisions for Purposes of Enforcement (Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999)
precis: Regulations Amending the PCB Regulations and the Regulations Designating Regulatory Provisions for Purposes of Enforcement (Canadian Environment Protection Act, 1999) in order to (1) allow for the continued use and storage of polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB)-containing equipment in nuclear, electrical, and military facilities, as well as museums, subject to certain conditions; (2) clarify that mixing PCB oil with non-PCB oil for the purposes of reducing its concentration is not allowed and, that laboratory tests are not required if the PCB concentration is already known by other means; (3) defer end-of-use deadline for certain PCB-containing electrical equipment to December 31, 2026, or beyond, subject to ministerial approval; and (4) make consequential amendments to certain other regulations to incorporate the provisions of the regulations.
